title: Radiocarpal vs. Midcarpal Motion
summary: Contrast the proximal radiocarpal condylar joint with the plane-like midcarpal joints, tying each to the arcs of flexion-extension and radial-ulnar deviation.
high_yield: Radiocarpal joint primarily handles flexion-extension initiation and absorbs 80% of axial load.
Midcarpal joint fine-tunes radial/ulnar deviation—show the alternating concave/convex surfaces.
Mention closed-packed positions (extension + radial deviation) for stability questions.
pitfalls: Students blur the two joint contributions; use dual gauges showing % contribution to motion arcs.
Avoid calling midcarpal joints hinge—reiterate plane/gliding nature.

animation_timeline.narration: Display radiocarpal joint surfaces with flexion-extension arc gauge (60° vs. 35°).
